Definition.Document:
Transformer Replacement Strategy using True Age Calculation

Objective

Knowing when to replace a substation power transformer is a difficult task.  When do you know you have utilized the full life of the transformer?  Most transformer manufacturers define the end of life as age 40.  However, lightly loaded transformers may not reach the true age of 40 until their 60th or 70th year in service.  Without the correct tools for trend analysis, the ability to evaluate the effects of loading beyond a transformer's nameplate rating over time would be extremely difficult to calculate, making it almost impossible to know a transformer's true age and when it should be replaced.

IEEE C57.91-2011


 

The IEEE C57.91-2011 standard provides algorithms for calculating the ageing acceleration factor for a given load and temperature and the percent loss of life of transformer insulation.  In the following worksteps, we combine temperature and loading data from real-time data historians with nameplate/characteristic data stored in SQL to calculate the true age of a system of transformers.

Link to Organizer Topic

Assemble Data

Process Data

  • Load and temperature data is stored in PI - step

Equipment data 

  • Equipment heat run properties are stored in an SQL database - step

Apply analytics

Hot spot temperatures 

  • Use Formula to calculate the equivalent continuous 24-hour prior load (root mean square) in actual MVA from load data stored in PI - workstep
  • Use Formula to calculate the winding hottest-spot temperature from the RMS and equipment heat run properties stored in SQL - workstep

Aging factor 

  • Use Formula with an adaptation of the Arrhenius reaction rate theory and the calculated winding hottest-spot temp to calculate the true age of the transformer insulation - workstep

Visualize 

  • See how hot spot temperature correlates with load using Scatterplot view - workstep
  • Use Scorecard tool to see Time Aged vs Time Elapsed - workstep

Scale Across Assets

  • Check out Time Aged for Transformer 2 using asset swap - workstep
  • Use Treemap to check for periods of high rate of aging for both transformers in Station 191 - workstep
  • "Zoom out" to see the whole region - workstep
  • Drill down to Station 59 and Transformer 4 - workstep
  • Shown in a table across assets

Results

  • Reduces CapEx by prioritizing replacement based on actual equipment condition
  • Improves system reliability to avoid $10's of millions in unplanned downtime and CapEx and premature replacement
  • Seeq application allows for
    • Aggregation of data from multiple datasources
    • Extrapolation of data to installation year
    • Rapid iteration across assets
  • Transformer true age can be just one part of a robust replacement strategy.  Other metrics could include:
    • Maintenance history
    • Deprecation value
    • Risk factors
      • Environmental (surrounding property)
      • Safety impacts
      • Reliability (restoration time / spare availability)
      • Customer impacts (counts / types)

Appendix

  • RMS2 (TRFM 1)
  • RMS3 (TRFM 1)
  • Use PI and equipment heat run properties - step
